review:
Lets be honest hardcore survival horror games are infrequent in this day and age more so if you don't care for any other type of horror games. Survival horror is a special term one that was elevated by the creator of resident evil and now this game. He's back and he brings back his tried and true staple of the genre. Remember this genre has its roots in 90s so the structure and the mechanics will throw most players off at first but those who know their way of a few classic games of the genre will know the methods but will also be tested because this very much a old meets new type of game. Bringing classic survival horror in a modern gaming market so expect to see some ubiquitous things like checkpoints,player upgrades,weapon upgrading and full on dlc expansions.
Story for this game will throw people off its not well told and requires attention to detail of environments and letters and documents just to get a hint of the characters,motives and past events. The game uses warping a lot and this i feel takes away from the overall attachment to each environment. As the settings and monsters are the real highlight. Due note that the game is brutally gore some of the way your character dies will shock you. And the difficulty has spikes expect to die a lot in your first playthrough but every new playthrough after at most you'll be annoyed as the becomes more enjoyable when you know how to tackle situations that were once difficult.
Its a visceral game unrelenting but a rewarding survival horror game that tests your ability to survive a nighmarish world.

review: First impressions well the Aesthetics aren't really my taste but that doesn't bother me when I'm wearing them. Material is all plastic that said they don't feel like they going to break after a few drops. The comfort levels are great cushion is soft they are light weigh so I forget I'm even wearing them, headband isn't the best tho it big enough for even the largest of heads but the material just doesn't feel to great but you do get used to it, clamping force is comfortable too it doesn't feel like ur heads getting crushes but enough to stay on your head. Sound quality leans toward the high side, highs being great mids coming out flat and lows good enough to give a lil punch but can become muddy if volume is to loud, the sound stage is very good determining where sound was coming from was never difficult. One thing that I'm really let down on is the Mic, the volume is really low and can hear background noise and a hint of static, using a USB sound card can help with all of that but you have to set the gain to the max  (also helps with sound) that being said testing the Mic on Skype and discord calls and game lobbies sounded fine with anyone's complaints is the background noise. Overall this headset is fine but should you get it well yes if you have a orange theme set up.

review:
This is a really cool Xbox One controller!

1) It IS wired, so if you are looking to stick with wireless this is not for you.  However, with the features of this controller, the battery would die extremely quickly anyway.  The wire is long enough where it reaches my couch, but not my usual "comfort" spot.  So I would have to sit a little closer to the TV that I would like on my 70" 4K HDR TV (minus 1 star).

2) The LED feature is really neat!  The center of the controller and the handles light up.  They are separate and can be controlled by the buttons on the back (top button for center, bottom for handles, and middle for the 3 brightness levels).  The first phases through every color available, the second pulses to different colors, and the rest are just the stable colors.  A not so "red" red, orange, and shades of green, blue and purple.  You can sync both sections together with good timing or have the to your specific customization.  Or if LED is not for you, too distracting for you or your significant other, you can simply turn the lights off.  I myself think it's a cool feature to keep on!  At least my wife will have something interesting to look at while I play Assassin's Creed...

3)  This controller simply feels VERY comfortable.  The buttons work well and it feels just like the quality of the Microsoft brand controllers!  It does not feel like the cheaper MadCatz of my teenage years.  It rumbles just like an original controller, has the microphone input.  It does it all!

So simply put, this is a wired Xbox One controller that feels and works up to par with the original controller with cool LED light features for a little less cost.

I'll update later if or when it craps out on me which could affect this score.  But as of now, Day 1....so far so good.

review:
Not only the best Resident Evil game but also one of the best videogames of all time.

My time with RE4 before this was with the PS2 version, the worst of all ports based on visuals.  On PS4 the game looks and plays great at a constant 60 fps.  Modern third person shooting games allow movement and shooting at the same time.  RE4 does not do that so it may take time to adjust.  The game is structured in such a way that it plays very well after getting used to this gameplay mechanic.

It is not as scary as other Resident Evil games but still has its scary moments from time to time.  Another positive aspect of RE4 is the wide variety of enemies and levels.  This keeps the game from getting repetitive.  And that is important because this game will easily last 20 hours for the main game alone.  That does not include the extras lake Ada's game.

Final question is which versions of RE4 are worth it?  All of them of course!  In more detail:
Best: PS4, Xbox One, recent PC release (2014).  The consoles have slightly better textures but no anti-aliasing.
2nd: PS3, Xbox 360 run at 720p and 30 fps, still excellent
3rd: Wii runs at 480p and 30 fps.  Some people actually think this is the best port due to the wiimote shooting controls
Last: Gamecube, PS2, 2005 PC release.  Gamecube still looks great but excludes extras.  PS2 has the worst graphics of all ports and some slowdown.  The first PC port was botched, poor controls, graphics (although the graphics could be fixed with mods).

Special thanks to Capcom for producing such a fine videogame.

review:
I recently purchased this game on the PSN as a digital download. Wow, this game is amazing!! The multiplayer is what most people are buying it for, and it's great. It's more robust and content filled than the original, and the controls are as good, or better than any FPS on the market. The frame rate is rock solid 60fps, and it helps because this game is crazy fast. One second your running on the side of a building, and flying through the air--the pilots are freakishly mobile. The next second your jumping in your Titan and wrecking the place, it's sooooo good. The single player campaign is, no joke, one of my favorite FPS campaigns, probably ever. It is incredible. It's got bits of Metroid prime, Bioshock, Mirrors Edge, and the film Pacific Rim, all wrapped in an amazing game and story that has you switching between on foot segments with a nice bit of platforming--it all works brilliantly--and sections in mechs where you take on bosses, and try different loadouts to perfect your character, it's really, really good.
For the ridiculously low price this game is selling for, everyone should buy it. You will easily get your money's worth.

review:
Like Saint's Row IV there's a lot of witty writing and banter between characters with a lot of references to pop and geek culture mixed with comic mischief

Instead of following one customized character. you can switch between dozens assembling a party of 3 to go on a mission at a time. I find this less personal as you're playing from a team perspective instead of a single character taking the lead. The narration, except for introduction of new character missions focus on the team instead of a single agent you are playing. The agent you select/switch off from the party of 3 gives off one liners at times given certain scenarios. There's barely any character development as you just get snippets of back story to go off of.

There's no open world to explore for the main story rather you go into a hub world to upgrade your stats/gear, and make purchases for your next mission. Each mission run from 5-15mins average depending on your skill level how much you upgrade your character. While playing through this game, I can't help but think this would go perfect on a handheld console like the Nintendo Switch due to its short mission structure.

There is an open world segment as you can explore the city of Seoul, but it's basically a territory gain mini-game where you have to take control legion bases scattered throughout the map. Unless you max out most of your characters it's almost impossible to take over all territories as once you take over a few, one that you captured already is regained by the enemy. Once you gain a territory, you can earn addition cash/exp through side quests within that territory

You unlock new characters through the main story or tackling side missions. Most new character you encounter have a better base stat and ability than your current party, so it encourages you to switch off, even though the newbie is of lower level.

All characters you encounter are unique in terms of personality (most be overly stereotypical), abilities, and play styles.
There's a lot of ways to upgrade your character stats though points from experience gained

There are 15 difficulty settings in the game each having different rewards upon completion. Depending on difficulty you set, you get different experience points and cash based on how fast you complete them. Thus you have to find a happy medium for advancement in this risk reward system

Graphics and style is very similar to Saints Row IV. Visuals are slightly better than SRIV, but not the best the PS4 can dish out. When there's a lot happening on screen, the frame rate may drop a bit (playing on the launch PS4). Menus have the iconic purple and white color scheme. Hand drawn cutscenes are a mixed bag and feels off at times due to the uneven lines in one scene and smooth line on the same character the next

Gameplay is your typical run-and-gun 3rd person shooter with a lot of random abilities mixed in like a special that makes a random AOE explosion around you, or one that de-buff enemy stats once they're in a certain range of you. Aiming is very generous in this game as you can land head shot fairly easily. You should be more focused on positioning than aiming due to it's fast paced nature. Most missions are basically the same and it get repetitive fast with the only motivation being to fully upgrade each character and listen in one their one liners

Story is your generic take over the world setup, but again the witty humor makes up for it.

Overall, if you want a variety of bit size missions instead of one epic tale in the tone of Saints Row IV, you should give this game a try

review:
My son is a lefty. He has been using my mice over the years and he just deals with it. So when I saw this affordable ambidextrous gaming mouse by SteelSeries (who I already use their keyboards and mouse pads) I was excited. Ambidextrous is good because it isn't left handed or right handed. It is just the same down the middle on each side and fully programmable.

How easy is it to program? I gave this to my 10 year old son and in 20 minutes he had custom colors, and was playing Minecraft without a keyboard. He had programmed different buttons for the WASD and space bar and so on... he loves it.

It feels and functions great, the programming software is easy to use and works well and the price is crazy cheap for a mouse of this quality with a trusted name brand like SteelSeries. The Sensei 310 Gaming mouse is a huge winner in my house!

review:
Every once and a while a game comes along that you realize once you play it, you've just played what will be considered a classic. Sometimes a game like this can make you mistakenly believe you actually enjoy a certain genre because it's just executed and done so well. For me those games are like a Zelda or a Final Fantasy. For the most part I can't stand those games as a series, but out them came classics that even I enjoy. Games like Zelda: A Link to the Past, and Final Fantasy X fit that description. Those are classics, but I've tried to play other games like them and I'm bored to death within minutes.

This game is an action/adventure RPG. I'm generally not a huge fan of this genre as a whole. Enough people I trust, though, said I should give this a shot. After purchasing and playing this game I tell you this game will stay in my collection until I die. The story is compelling. The acting is amazing. The gameplay is absolute perfection. Crafting is simple, easy, and actually makes sense! Saving is a breeze. Difficulty is hard enough. For those who demand a greater challenge, after beating the game you're given a new difficulty level to torture you with if you feel so inclined. I haven't cared about characters this much since playing games like Metal Gear Solid and the Mass Effect Trilogy.

If I had to gripe about this game it would be that it is so long, traveling the map can get cumbersome at times, and there are collectibles to get that really add no significant value to the game. There is a feature where you can fast travel around the map. Towards the end of the game I was doing this quite a bit. For me as a parent, I can't devote too much time to a game. So it took me quite a few months of off and on gameplay to beat this one. You can easily put around 60 to 70 hours into this game. That is more than enough. However, it was well worth it. That in itself is a testimate to how good this game really is. 10 hours give or take an hour is usually my breaking point. If I have to play any longer than that I usually move on to something else. This one, however, kept me engaged.

Side quests here, too, actually bring some depth to the story. I found myself actually wanting to finish these side quests. These also do quite a bit to help your character especially towards the end of the game.

I hate to say this, but even this game at the full price of $60, which it isn't anymore, is more than worth the asking price for this game. I always wait for things to go on sale or take advantage of the Prime pricing. I never pay $60 for a game. I only paid about 45 for this one, and it has been worth every penny. The creators of the Killzone series really outdid themselves here. Play this game. You more likely than not will not be disappointed.

review:
Good Lord this game is gorgeous.  Granted, every game on PS4 that is not a port job (e.g. Metro Redux) is very pretty, but this one is truly exceptional in its graphical appearance.  My eyes were popping constantly in my first play-through.
The gameplay is also exceptional with good tight controls, interesting environments, a variety of weapons, double-jumps and wall-run maneuvers in the environment, and lots of features and options.  Very well-done game overall.
Also it doesn't take very long to respawn at the last checkpoint after I die.  Many games will take a long time loading the entire level or section, before you can resume playing after you die.  Not this one.  It's fast.
I'm now playing through a 2nd time in an attempt to get all the Pilot Helmets (collectibles) and I'm having nearly as much fun as I did the first time.
The only downside is that the single-player campaign is quite short, in my opinion.
I rarely give 5-star reviews but this one is deserving.  If you like action, shooter, and/or adventure games, give this one a try.  Rated M for mature.

review:
As huge a fan as I am of the Mass Effect trilogy, I must say this game did not meet my expectations for the franchise. I bought Andromeda on launch and really powered through the main story. I had heard there was bad press but I am usually able to filter it out. The gameplay is nice and feels about on par with ME3, my high mark for the series.

I take great umbrage with the open world concept. The Mass Effect trilogy hooked me in with sharp narrative, not this sprawling mess of a story that has no urgency to it. That's the most disappointing part of this game to me - the story. I understand where the game was coming from and where it was trying to go, but it was really poorly executed, hackneyed and derivative. None of the themes of the series rang true in ME:A and it really stuck out as an outlier.

I finished the game and set it down. I played each trilogy game half a dozen times, but I had had enough Andromeda after 1 play through.

review:
This is a supremely useful tool for playing Pokemon GO, and for really optimizing the way you play. It has changed my mindset about how I approach the game, for the better. It is very handy to have on me constantly, picking up Pokemon and stops I would have otherwise missed. It's helped greatly in grinding away higher levels (35 as of this review) and has helped greatly in my effort to stash stardust.

It's not perfect though. It can disconnect if left inactive long enough, but I've never had an issue reconnecting. Originally, I kept it on a shirt pocket, but it kept trying to escape, so I just wear it as a wristband now. I don't mind flaunting my nerdiness, but some might, so it could be an issue for you.

Overall, I'm very pleased with the GO+ and I'd recommend it to most people who play a lot of Pokemon GO.

review:
I recalled hearing what a disaster GTA IV Online was and thanked myself for never going there, but rather creating my own Multi Theft Auto San Andreas, IV Multiplayer, and Five M servers that were 100% enjoyable all the time. I worked night and day on them for years, learning Lua, Squirrel, and JavaScript in the process of building them for the endless enjoyment tens of thousand of players who've visited them have shared in return for all my free labor over the past five years. Grand Theft Auto V, costing $250 million USD to make has sold 75 million units with a true cost of just under $4 per unit earning $4,750,000,000 in gross profit.

Grand Theft Auto Online has a couple of good things that sometimes work right, and can be down right amazing to play. Everything else about GTAO is otherwise broken.

The greatest and most easily fixable flaw in the GTAO experience is loading... Load times are 5-15 times as long as they should be, meaning what should take 15 seconds, can take 2-4 minutes, and that is if it hasn't crashed entirely. You will never know which is true. Until you've sat at a loading screen for 10 minutes only to conclude it is never going to load ever. Unlike the last screen you sat at for 9 minutes that did finally load. 50% of your time in GTAO will be thrown away waiting for things to load. It goes through a ridiculous amount of world loading even when it is not at all needed. I have built GTA V servers for GTA-MP, FiveMP, RageMP, and FiveM. It was shocking how horrible the load times of GTAO were. If GTAO were a single server on any of those systems, there would be no one using it. (7mb DSL, USA capable of loading 60GB a day)

The second worst part of the GTAO experience is the missions. I have written a dozen GTA missions on my various servers and wish it were a hundred missions because that is what writing a dozen good missions feels like. A mission must be written and rewritten and rerewritten, debugged, redebugged, and reredebugged. The GTA V single players missions all worked perfectly for me which is additionally why the online missions were so surprising. They were absolutely the worst GTA missions you have ever seen from any game. Worthy of a Vice City Redux perhaps. Go from point A to point B to shoot fish in a barrel. Made difficult only by the addition of team players who are always the worst players you've ever met. In addition to the missions being totally buggy. Vehicles that won't move being their most frequent flaw. I ran one mission over and over for 3 hours. It was maybe a 5 minute mission. Still haven't beaten it. Never died once.

The GTAO Youtube videos are all a poorly conceived tapestry of holywood lies. GTAO is a 500 million dollar "sharkcard" scam for profit. None of what they depict in the videos is available in GTAO the way they depict it. There is no community to speak of. There is no enjoyment to be had from it. There is nothing but misery, horror, and the worst socio-political indoctrination you have ever imagined from their "unrated" online content of the missions' dialog, the likes of which you couldn't find if you spent all day everyday on a drug binging biker hangout tour of the worst ghettos in the world during the post-apocalypse.

GTAO is the lowest common denominator theory in action, cashing in on a deader than dead franchise. If ever you enjoyed the miracle that was GTA III, the experience that was San Andreas or even the scatterbrained IV... run from this game and anything that follows at full speed. Grand Theft Auto is dead. Rockstar is dead. Take2 has taken enough. But don't believe my proclamation that they are a dead franchise since San Andreas and Red Dead. Buy it for yourself and see. It is the only way you will learn. You are a brainless cash machine and they have no daily limit.

I met a guy in JC3MP recently who told me GTA V was banned in his country so he couldn't go play it. I said wow. Sounds nice.

review:
As someone who is reluctant to "early adopt" because of getting burned before (**cough** Palm Pre), I waited a year to get this and have not been disappointed in the least! What an incredible revolution in gaming. You become so immersed in the games that you forget what's going on around you in real life. I am excited to see some of the creativity in newer games coming out as there is a LOT of potential with this platform. When you play the games, you feel as though you are there. This also does not feel like an extension of the PS4, but rather an entirely different gaming system.

Some minor criticisms:
- As others mentioned, the cord can be annoying attached to the headset. Speaking of which, there are a LOT of cords with this system.
- Don't expect the graphics to blow you away especially you've been using a PS4 Pro w/4k TV like myself (it's realistic enough but nowhere near the resolution or clarity of 4k gaming)
- Sony did some smart things with making it easy to adjust the headset to your head, but I still find myself having to constantly adjust it while wearing it because the screen can get slightly blurry. It does fit well with my glasses though so if you wear them you should be good.

review: These chargers rock, I have had the standard charge n play kit for Xbox One for about a year and it started to sporadically charge, most likely as I wrap the cord every time. Now I just drop it in the cradle and wait for the indicator lights to start blinking, when they stay solid its charged. A full charge usually lasts about a day and a half. So as long as you don't forget to drop it in the cradle after finishing you will be good to go. I will update my review in about 6 months to see if it still holds the charge as well as it does right now. Also I got the two pack so I can leave one at home and one to travel with = SCORE!!  The way these blocks link together is very cool so in theory if you have 2-4 controllers you can centralize them. The only CON if you consider it is the charge light indicator. It flashes repeatedly as the controller charges which doesn't bother me at all but, I can see that this would bother some people especially in a dark room. So all in all these things are nice. BTW the charge cable is super easy to lose so keep track of it as you can charge via USB or included wall adaptor. Well have a good day/evening and thanks for reading.

review:
Pros: great graphics, variety of gameplay, voice acting, amount of content
Cons: hard to follow story, gameplay seriously flawed, controls

First off it is easy to see why RE fans would not like this game.  Much of it plays like Gears of War or Call of Duty.  Those are fine games but if that is not what you want you would be unsatisfied.

Graphics are really good and framerate is great.  The voice acting is above video game standards.  There are multiple characters to play the game with, resulting in many hours of play.  I did not play it on previous consoles but apparently they added the dlc in this version, nice.

However, the game has lots of serious, serious flaws.
*can't pause game unless playing offline, and game selects online by default
*game does not pause when mixing healing items or switching weapons
*game controls are difficult to use and poorly explained.  Examples: qte circling actions with analog sticks are meant to be done with both sticks, not just one.  Tip: change the aiming icon to laser sight like in RE4 to make aiming easier (they should have enabled this by default).
*because the game storyline is told from multiple characters, it is really confusing.  I ended up finding a faq online tellilng me which order to play the chapters in order to make sense of the story.

Another example of flawed gameplay: on one level you are running down a train track and a train comes suddenly.  You are supposed to hit a few buttons as a qte event to avoid the train.  Thing is that I was not on the track at the time so the train should not have hit me.  Obviously the developers were forcing the qte event even though it did not make any sense given what was happening onscreen.

Another problem: zombies are bullet sponges.  Which is fine except that sometimes I found them not taking damage when shooting again after stunning them.  Or perhaps the animations were not there for multiple gunshots.  Either way it detracts from the game.

In the end this is a controversial game that some will love and others will hate.  As of Sept 2017 you can get it for a cheap price.  At discount probably worth a buy as long as you are aware of its many flaws.

review: Time travel, fantastical adventurous princesses, apocalyptic futures, that is just some of the beauty of the jrpg chrono trigger. A adventure of time and space. review:
First things first. If you're not very good at driving vehicles in video games, then don't even bother picking this one up because it's just going to frustrate you and probably give you a headache. Only get this game if you're a fan of the series, enjoy tough challenges and have tons of patience. I bought this game since I have already had the other 2 Driver games for the Playstation. It's the same concept as the previous titles, except this one adds the element of a 3rd person shooter, so in a way, it's sort of similar to that of a GTA game, though watered down some.

The graphics are pretty decent. Most if not every vehicle in this game handles differently, including acceleration, speed and steering. This is where some of the difficulty comes in, so make sure to go to the "Take A Ride" mode and get yourself familiar with all of the vehicles, because you're going to be using a lot of them throughout the entire game. The vehicles in this game range from sports cars, to big rigs, to boats and a lot others. The on foot controls are alright, though some of the buttons do seem like they have a split second delay on them. Just like the other 2 games, you play as the undercover cop Tanner, working for the bad guys to get info on whats going on. The entire game takes place in 3 different locations. Miami, Florida. Nice, France. And Istanbul, Turkey. Each location has their own set of vehicles, so you won't find the same vehicle in each location.

Most of the missions consists of driving from point A to point B. Other missions include tailgating and chases. And lastly are the on foot missions. The on foot missions are fairly easy. Most of them just require you to simply shoot your way to the end of the mission while others have you interact with buttons, cranes, etc. Though some of the on foot missions do have driving strung together on them, so it's almost like 2 missions inside 1 whole mission. If you die or fail at any point during most of these missions, you have to start from the very beginning of the mission, though some missions are actually nice enough to give you checkpoints so that you don't have to redo the whole thing over again just to get to the part where you died or failed.

The point A to point B and tailgate missions are fairly easy as well. Some of the point A to point B missions have a set time limit. The tailgate missions just consist of following enemy vehicles around the map until they get to their destination all while making sure to keep an eye on your detection meter. If you stray too far away, you'll lose sight of the vehicle and if you get too close, the enemy will become suspicious, both resulting in a failed mission. I personally find this to be kind of annoying since you have a radar in the corner of the screen that shows you where the enemy vehicle is, even if your kind of far away from them. Nonetheless, all of the enemy vehicles go somewhat slow during these missions and they all take the same route during every playthrough, so it's really not that hard to get past these segments.

The chase missions are the toughest missions in the entire game. Your objective in these missions is to chase down the enemy vehicle that is trying to escape, most of which usually always ends up in a shoot out at the end. Sometimes you will be required to shoot at the enemy vehicles while driving. What makes these missions tough is that you must keep up with the enemy vehicle throughout the entire chase mission. If you're too slow going around a turn or if you end up wrecking into an object that can stop you dead in your tracks, 9 times out of 10, the enemy will end up getting away, resulting in a failed mission. However, it is possible to catch up to the enemy vehicle if you happen to wreck or go too slow around a turn, but like I said, the chances of that happening are very slim. You can't really memorize the patterns either because for most of the chase missions, the enemy vehicle will always take a different route. The only mission that I've found where the enemy vehicle takes the same route during every playthrough was the very last chase mission in the game.

If you're really good at driving games, want a challenge or just like the Driver series, then pick this one up.

review: I bought this little gem many years ago at a local game store back when the PS2 was still in it's prime. It was one of the best purchases that I've ever made for my PS2. I'm not sure which version mine is. All I know is that it's the yellow disc that says "Get More Game" on it. I also have a Gameshark 2 version 3, but nothing can compare to the Codebreakers disc. The interface is easier to use, and all of the cheats for the games work, unlike with the Gameshark 2, the games tend to freeze a lot when I activate a cheat from it. It just really sucks that you have to manually put in the codes now instead of just downloading them on to your memory card from the Codebreakers servers since the servers shut down. Anyways, I'm the type of gamer that loves playing video games, but in a world where there are thousands upon thousands of games, I hate wasting a bunch of time on one level or one game that I'm unable to get past. I just want to enjoy the main story of the game while getting the most out of what the game has to offer and then move on to the next game. Too many games, not enough time to play them all. But, thanks to Codebreakers, this disc has helped me get through some of the tougher parts of some games as well as made a lot of games replayable for me because of the amount of things that you can do in a game when you have cheats activated. It literally becomes a whole different ball game. Explore restricted areas, become invincible, take down a whole army of enemies, unlock every unlockable in a game, and modify the game to your liking by swapping character skins and making the AI stand there as if nothing is happening. It's a shame we don't see too many games these days with cheat codes included, and when we do, it's usually in the form of DLC.

now as far as the story *SPOILERS
 "it begins at full speed, with protagonist Lara Croft and Jonah, one of her companions from the last game, journeying into the frigid mountains of Siberia. Through some flashbacks  both in cutscene and playable form  we learn that Lara is on the trail of an artifact and a lost city, two myths that her father swore were real before a tragic death. As the adventure progresses, Lara finds herself up against Trinity, a shadowy organization looking for the same historical discoveries for more malevolent purposes. Lara ignores her and organises an expedition to Syria, hoping to uncover the tomb of the Prophet of Constantinople, a key figure in the legend of Kitezh. Although successful, the tomb is empty, and Lara is interrupted by Trinityan ancient order of knights that now exists as a paramilitary organization investigating the supernaturaland their leader Konstantin. As she flees, Lara discovers a symbol etched into the tomb that she links to a book on Russian religious history in her father's study. A Trinity assassin steals the book, prompting Lara and her friend Jonah to give chase in Siberia. When the two are separated after an avalanche, Lara is forced to go on alone.

Lara discovers that Trinity has taken over a Soviet-era mining installation as a base of operations in the search for Kitezh. She is caught attempting to retrieve the book and placed in a prison cell with Ana. Konstantin forces Lara to reveal what she knows by slowly strangling Ana in front of her, but Lara is unable to tell anything of use. Ana then reveals herself to be Konstantin's sister and Trinity's spy who has been manipulating her father. The two interrogate her as to the whereabouts of the "Divine Source", an artifact believed to grant immortality. Lara escapes, and in the process aids Jacob, a mysterious stranger who leads her through the mines into the valley beyond. Jacob is revealed to be the leader of the Remnant, the descendants of the followers of the Prophet of Constantinople. As Lara aids in their resistance against Trinity, she begins to learn more about the deathless Prophet and the lost city of Kitezh. After being branded a heretic and pursued by the Order of Trinity, the Prophet and his followers resettled in Russia, where they built Kitezh. However, spurred on by agents of Trinity, the Mongol Hordes led by Genghis Khan attacked the city, and the Prophet was forced to sacrifice it to protect the Divine Source. The Remnant escaped and settled in the area, vowing to defend the city's secret. Jacob warns her that although the Divine Source exists, it is not what she expects it to be. Konstantin's forces repeatedly attack the Remnant, believing them to be heretics and justifying the slaughter as God's will. However, Lara discovers that Ana is dying and has been manipulating her brother to find the Divine Source and save her.
Jacob and Lara decide that the only way to protect the Divine Source is to retrieve it before Trinity can. In order to do this, Lara recovers the Atlas, an artifact that serves as a map of Kitezh. She is reunited with Jonah, who has been spying on Trinity forces, and they locate the path into the city. However, Konstantin has been aware of Jonah's presence and let him go free in the hopes that he would lead them to Lara. Trinity then attacks and take Jonah and the Atlas. Lara goes after Trinity and tries to rescue Jonah, but before she can free him, Konstantin stabs him and escapes. Lara takes Jonah to Jacob, who miraculously heals Jonah. Jacob then admits that he is the deathless Prophet himself. With Trinity advancing on the glacier that rests over Kitezh, Lara is forced to enter the city through the Path of the Deathless where she encounters the Deathless Ones, the immortal guardians of the city. Following the journals of a Trinity agent embedded in the Mongolian forces, Lara realizes the truth of Jacob's warning: the Divine Source grants immortality to the person who beholds it at the cost of their sense of self, and the Deathless Ones are the hollow immortal inhabitants of Kitezh who no longer know anything else but defending the city. As Lara enters Kitezh, the Remnant rally to attack the Deathless Ones, giving her time to reach the heart of the city. She encounters Konstantin blocking the path and mortally wounds him; he dies in disbelief that he was not carrying out God's will, but Ana's. Before his death, he claims that Lara's father did not commit suicide, but was in fact murdered by Trinity. Lara is too late to stop Ana from retrieving the Divine Source, a large glowing crystal, but wrests it from her before Ana can use it. Lara then smashes the Divine Source, killing the Deathless Ones and taking away Jacob's immortality. However, he is happy that his death has finally come and thanks Lara for bringing his end as he peacefully disintegrates. In the aftermath, Jacob's daughter Sofia takes over the Remnant. Jonah recovers from his wounds and joins Lara in planning their next expedition, with Lara vowing to investigate more of the world's mysteries as well as thwart Trinity's plans. A post-credits scene shows Lara and Ana leaving Russia, two weeks before Lara returned to the manor. Lara confronts Ana about whether Ana killed her father. Ana denies it, despite admitting that Trinity gave her the order. Before she can reveal anything else, a sniper shot hits Ana, killing her instantly. The sniper asks his unseen superior about killing Lara, but is told to stand down for the time being."

review:
The POWER A amiibo End Level Display is a really awesome amiibo display solution. Granted, it's only really got spots for 6 amiibos (though you can get a 7th right next to the base of the flag), but it really looks great and has that wonderful Nintendo retro feel to it (anyone who's ever played the original Super Mario Bros. is going to love it). It's a great display piece and a wonderful way to show off your amiibos.

Assembly is a snap, as the blocks basically go together like building blocks. You can customize it, if you wish, although I think the standard end level design is what most people will go with. It stays together pretty well, and while it jiggles around a bit while moving, it hasn't fallen apart yet (and this is being played-with by 5 and 7 year-olds...it was an early birthday gift for my oldest). Larger amiibos probably won't have enough room to fit on any but the top blocks (Bowser, I'm looking at you), but that's a minor quibble.

Ultimately, this is just a great display for amiibos and a great gameroom decoration in general.

review: Growing up with The Legend of Zelda and A Link to the Past set the bar fairly high fairly early on in my gaming career.  I never had a Nintendo 64, and I did try Windwaker on my Game Cube, but couldn't get into it.  I was very excited when I found out this game was on the 3DS, as it seemed to pay homage to A Link to the Past, and it definitely delivers!  It feels like a proper Zelda game.  The controls are very responsive, as I'd expect.  Overall, I'm pleased with the graphics.  The developers did a wonderful job rendering the game, and the ability to jump into the walls adds a very nice dimension to the game play (no pun intended) without feeling too gimmicky.  This game definitely scratches that nostalgia itch while simultaneously feeling current.  This is a slam dunk!

review:
Definitely one of the best looking versions of Code: Veronica X. It's a solid port with no technical issues and no corners cut. The game plays exactly like the original, and the only changes have been to the graphics:

* Runs in HD. It's surprising how good such an old game looks in high-res!
* Better atmospheric lighting and more detailed shadows.
* Better water effects.
* No fog effects.

The fog was needed to hide far-away objects which the 360 has no problem with, but I think it also added atmosphere which is now missing in some scenes. Not a deal breaker.

If you can live without HD then the Gamecube port is probably the next best version.

review:
SMT IV: Apocalypse is fantastic. If you liked the earlier SMT games like Soul Hackers you'll feel right at home with this one. It fixes a lot of things about SMT IV that were turn-offs to long time fans of the series and is a sequel to the game, not a remix or re-imagining of SMT IV.

The music is top-notch, especially because Shoji Meguro isn't involved (finally!) and Persona veteran Kenichi Tsuchiya is amongst the composers. It's a different sound from the original Persona games, but it's still great and lacks all of the repetitive musical tropes and tired J-Pop appeal Meguro relies on too heavily in his later work. The voice acting is also superb, not a single character has a unexceptional delivery.

Battles are fast-paced which offsets the high encounter rate, though you can see enemies and outrun them when needed. The plot is interesting and has a lot of twists and turns, and the character development is pretty good. There's a lot of new faces in the game, but they are all unique and interesting. It's a moderately long game and you definitely will put some serious time into it.

The graphics are a mixed bag; the backgrounds and 3D chacter/demon models are very well made. The demon portraits were made by several different artists and one of them is absolutely terrible, so it's jarring to cycle through your demon roster and see very impressive illustrations and then some amateur ones. Some of the background objects like trees and bushes have a bizarrely low polygon count and look like something from an original Playstation game. On the whole it's all above average, however, just a few things stick out.

Like all modern Atlus games the translation is well done but rife with spelling and grammatical errors. For some reason both Atlus and Aksys Games steadfastly refuse to proof-read their work.

I'd highly recommend this game to any SMT fans, especially those of you enjoyed Strange Journey and Soul Hackers. It's fine return to form and shows that Atlus can still make good games for hardcore fans even if they also have to churn out garbage like Persona 3 and 4 for casual gamers to make money.

review:
I loved DQ VIII on the PS2, but there are two major problems with the 3DS version of the game:

1. No stereoscopic support. The game isn't in 3D.

2. The primary font used for the bulk of all text in the game is incredibly blurry. This was done by scaling down and anti-aliasing the original PS2 font and then resizing it to fit the 3DS screen. It's very hard to look at after a while.

I'd suggest trying the game before you buy it to see if you can stand to read the blurry font. It may be fine for some, for me it was a deal breaker.

review: Works better than expected. The PS2 is a great console with classic games. No complaints from me. Always make sure you check for games you would want to play before buying a console. (WARNING) The slim version can get really hot. Also make sure you are buying from a trusted seller and that the console is in PERFECT working condition. Trust me you don't want a half functioning PS2. review:
Finally played it many, many years after release.

I completely feel like both 13-2 and LR ruined the good memories of FF13 for me.

LR plays drastically different than the other two (new combat system, new gameplay).  It's got a time/day limit that I've been told is similar to Zelda Majora's Mask - I do not like games that have time limits. Overall gameplay is pretty good, they kinda forced a difficulty spike to encourage multiple replays.  Side quests are not optional.  Story is cheesy.

I didn't absolutely hate it, but I feel incredibly ambivalent toward this game.  I'm hard pressed to give any positives (not even music, at least 13-2 had really good music).  I didn't absolutely hate this game, but while it was okay when I played it, I left the game with an overall negative feeling/impression.

At the end of the day, I definitely feel like the sequels ruined the original for me.  Now that I'm done with these two, I plan to pretend they don't exist in the FF13 timeline lol.

If you liked FF13 a lot, I'd say skip the sequels so they don't ruin the original story and characters.

If you liked FF13 but specifically hated just the linearity - try 13-2 and/or LR

If you liked FF13 but specifically hated the paradigm shift combat system - try LR

If you didn't like FF13 - why are you reading this review.

review:
Ok look, it's NOT as bad as the reviews make it seem like. Glitches and bugs? Yes there were plenty, but the update completely fixes it! Combat sucks? I don't see that at all. I actually thought it's a nice improvement with all the new moves, and they made the fight more realistic as well. And let's face it, that finishing stab is the coolest I've seen since Revelations. Storyline? I thought it's pretty engaging, especially with the adorable girlfriend (not trying to spoil anything), maybe still a little cliche (cuz it's always that revenge story), but that doesn't take away the fun. And let's face it, the graphics is just hands down amazing!! The amount of details, the scenery, the people and everything, is just amazing. Great job Ubisoft.

BUT of course it's not perfect. My problem with it, however, is the fact that LITERALLY EVERY MISSION IS THE SAME. Basically, every single mission is to "infiltrate this place and kill that person." It gets so boring after like 10 of those!!

But overall I thought it's a pretty decent game, and definitely lived up to the AC standard. I admit that I don't really give a sh*t about the protagonist Arno, but just for gaming purpose he's just as fun to play as our favorite Ezio!!

review: Prey is a reboot no one asked for, and it has nothing to do with the original 2006 game (Prey - Xbox 360). I really liked the Native American / alien abduction aspect of the original, but sadly, that's all done away with. The new Prey has many problems. It's basically BioShock in space, from the over-used art-deco visual motifs down to the way "neuromods" are injected into your body (skills/abilities). The game map itself is very small, taking place entirely on a space station, which has about 12 sections. To get from one section to the next, you have to suffer a 1-2 minute load time. If you play this game from start to finish, you will literally waste several hours of your life on load screens. This is absolutely the worst aspect of the game, and possibly a limitation of the CryEngine. It really takes you out of the experience, and I dreaded having to go through a door. Compare this to Zero Dawn Horizon, which is free roam and open world, with no load times. Most rooms and computer terminals are initially locked and you have to find the corresponding keycard or password in another part of the station to progress. So typical gameplay is, go to one section of the station, find the card/code then go back to the other part of the station. You will have to travel back and forth between sections many times. Some locks require hacking to open, which you can do once you've acquired the right hacking skill level. Hacking an item opens a timed maze mini-game. Get the cursor into the target and avoid the walls of the maze, which shock and slow you down. Some doors absolutely require the appropriate card to open and are not hackable. The weapons are very limited, underpowered, and lame: shotgun, Gloo gun (shoots incapacitating foam), stun gun, pistol, wrench, etc. The game is set in 2032 which is not that far in the future, but really, some better, more original weapons would've been more fun. I ended up using the wrench most of the game because most of the weapons were useless. The pistol, for example, does a paltry 12 damage! 12! Enemy design is also very limited. You'll see only about a dozen different kinds of aliens, which either float, scuttle, or are bipedal. There's not much variation. One aspect of the game I did enjoy was the materials recycler, but maybe that's because of my OCD. Put unwanted items in the bin and convert them to basic materials cubes, which can be fed into a Fabricator to make items/weapons/upgrades. I finished the game, out of nothing more than pure stubbornness. I wish I hadn't. The ending is extremely unsatisfying. I won't spoil it for you, but it's really disappointing and made me feel even worse about wasting many hours on the game. It's a bit disingenuous to have spent so much time playing to find out that the ending is what it is, and that your actions have no consequence. If you rescue crew, there's no reward at the end. You are also lied to. One of the objectives in a side mission is to "escape Talos I". If you complete the step, the game immediately ends with a voiceover! Save your time and money.

review:
Hands down one of the best RGB Keyboards ever.

My last true 16.8 Million color RGB keyboard was a Blackwidow Chroma 2014 with their clicky Kailh switches. They felt okay, but they were very loose and mushy. Not to mention the spacebar wire broke after 5 months of use. This Strafe has Cherry MX Brown switches and they feel and sound amazing. When it comes to switch quality, look no further than Corsair.

The design is slightly different than the Corsair K70. This keyboard is made of strong plastic, which does NOT pick up finger prints! (thank god.) The cable is not braided, the switches are not exposed like the K70. For example, the K70's design is more similar to the Blackwidow X While the Strafe has a similar design to the regular Blackwidow Chroma with a white back-plate. Oh, and there is no volume wheel, but you can change the volume using FN + F5, F6 Or F7, so you still have volume control. The overall design is very nice. You also have a USB Pass through as well, which is nice. The RGB Version comes with a wrist rest, which is nice considering how the original strafe does not include one. However, I don't find it as comfortable as the one that comes with the K70 Lux non-rgb. But I won't let a wrist rest affect my final verdict.

Finally, the lighting. The lighting on this keyboard is beautiful. This keyboard has a white back-plate which makes the colors look brighter and more vibrant. Each key is individually backlit so you can change the color each key without it affecting others. On the sides of the keyboard you have the light strips, but from as far as I know they only stay white, it would be nice if could change the color of them like on the K95 Platinum.

Finally, the software. CUE Has gotten easier to use over the years. It's pretty easy to use now if you don't have "advanced mode" turned on in the software. Once you know how to use the software is when you realize how powerful this keyboard can be.

So, would I recommend it? YES! If you don't mind not having a volume wheel, braided cable or metal build quality, then this is the keyboard for you!

review:
Nice packaging, The figure is well make and it's easy to swap out faces (comes with 3), although it can't quite do Beck's signature pose. The bottom of the stand is hand numbered out of 10,000. The art book and poster are also very nice. The DLC card said it expired 02/09/2017 but it worked fine for me today (09/27/2017). I'd say the extras are worth the price. As for the game itself, which I didn't factor into my stars, I'm a huge Mega Man fan and I'd consider this game average for that realm. It's not Mega Man 2 or 3, but it's not X7 either (imo one of the worst). If you're looking for something better in the retro platforming genre, Mighty Gunvolt Burst is a much better game(and a great game period), and as I've heard stated many times, what Mighty No. 9 should have been.

For those interested, I'd rate the condition of the box I received a 7.5/10. There were stickers on it, but they were easy enough to remove without tearing the box (it's very glossy). The corners showed wear and there was a tiny tear in the top of the slip cover. And like a seasoned prostitute, it had that "I've been handled quite a bit" look to it.

review:
I love this game!! Of course, it is not like the old school games, Resident Evil 0, 1, 2, 3 and 4 but I like the fact that Capcom makes different styles of Resident Evil games because I'm a big fan of the Franchise. Resident Evil 5 is more action packed than scary but I still get to shoot and kill zombies and mutated monsters. And I like having my partner with me too. She can hold stuff and we can swap and give things to one another. When I finish this one, I'm gonna get Resident Evil 6, because I didn't get a chance to play Resident Evil 5 or 6 on the consoles, (XBOX 360 and PlayStation 3) before the present consoles. So, it's new to me. And the graphics are really good but I find the tone of color odd.

To the movies. They never made a Resident Evil movie that's like the old school Resident Evil games 0-4, which would be pretty cool. But with Resident 5, they may have finally made a video game that's similar to the movies. RE 5's story may be different from the movies but it is action-packed just like the movies. I happen to like the movies too. So maybe... That is why I like RE5 and I can see why it is compared to "Dead Rising 2." With all said, I like that this game is kinda opposite from the ones before it. Just fun action!

 So if your ready to spend 150+ on the controller plus 25 for replacement grips plus another 5-10 for bumpers. More power to you. Just remember this controller is not Elite. The designers of this controller seem to have cut too many corners. And, the warranty is only 90 days with Microsoft.

review: In many ways, this is like the ultimate One Piece game. It takes you through all of the major arcs up through Dressrosa (which has an improvised ending because the arc was not complete by the time this game was finished; for reference, there is no gear 4th in this game). You plow through the story putting down hundreds of enemies per stage with unique abilities and character strategies. When you finish story mode (which you will likely never tire of reliving), there is an exhaustive challenge mode where you take on dozens of various stages. The biggest drag of this game is that characters have to have "level breaks" to get past level 50. Definitely buy this game if you are a One Piece fan. It is English subbed with Japanese audio.

review:
Endless customization doesn't actually mean you'll find a sweet spot. This was an interesting experiment for sure, but after trying to use it for 2 weeks, i just could not put up with the learning curve VS benefits.

I've seen the numerous videos supporting the Steam Controller. How it can be more accurate than a traditional X Box pad. For me personally, the discomfort was just too great. The track pad was just never accurate for me, no matter how much i tweaked it, the fact that i have to center my thumbs constantly on a flat pad made it hell for FPS, and for the much advertised Point and Click games that it works with? It....does work. But i always found myself reaching for a mouse.

Other reviews have said this the best. The Steam controller is an enabler. It makes games like RTS's that are impossible on the gamepad possible. Whether or not you WANT that feature, at the cost of comfort, is up to you. I don't recommend this if you want to play on your PC where you already have a mouse and keyboard as a better alternative.

review:
This was a really fun game to play, and it was a pretty easy game to earn the Platinum trophy as well. The game looks are plays nicely on the PS Vita. The story is pretty short though, but it's fairly interesting. There are several difficulty levels to play this game on, so if it seems too easy--you can easily turn up the challenge. Enemy A.I. is pretty predictable, and you can deal with enemies fairly well when you have cover.

The online community for this game is absolutely positively DEAD. If you're expecting to play any online content whatsoever, forget about it. I've literally waited for hours in a lobby hoping players would join me, and it never happened. There's no interest in this game by players it seems, so be warned--especially if you're going for the online trophies; You'll need a friend to help boost you.

Overall this is a good game, and I'm glad that I played it. However, there's just no replayability in this title after you finish it. It took me about 6 hours to complete the single player campaign, and I spend about another 12 more hours on/off trying to find a person to play with online--which is futile at this point. I recommend getting this game used, or at a discount if you can find it. It's still fun to play, and if you're a trophy hunter it's worth doing.

review:
I love my Razer Deathadder. I really do. Until it started glitching out within a few months, and died within a year. Whether its the scroll click button or the left click sticking, most mouses just have some sort of oddity with them.

Not this one. After 6 months of stress testing it, through RTS and FPS games, along with usual daily usage and web browsing extensively with the scroll wheel, there hasn't once been an issue.

Its comfortable, very customization with the supplied mouse weights, and the software is easy to use. It fits my rather meaty hand well too, so if you have a fat palm, fret not. This will be comfortable. Probably. How should i know.

But the build quality really is fantastic. I'll update this review when the mouse breaks.

review:
First of all a small explanation in case you are not familiar with Plus. Welcome to PS world.

-PlayStation Plus is available to all PlayStation 4, PlayStation 3, and PS Vita owners.
-While the membership is active youll receive six free downloadable video games every single month, you will receive and email every time they change the titles(Note that you can add these games to your library even without downloading them if you want to have a reminder that they are available in case you decide to play them that month).
-All PlayStation Plus members receive weekly discounts up to 75% on games, add-ons, season passes, and other digital content. While also providing access to limited discounts only for members.
-One of the most important features is the Online multiplayer unlocked for every single games(excluding MMORPGs that are owned by different companies, ie Final Fantasy 14).
-While your PS4 is set as your main console, every single person who also has a profile in your console will be able to use your purchased content, yes you got that right.
-Besides all this you can also upload your save files to the cloud to always have a back up, no one likes loosing all their progress. Access to exclusive betas will also be provided.

Regarding the membership itself, most of the times after purchasing the code it will instantly be added to the library, although in some cases it can take about 1 hour. You get a full year which is the best way to use the PS Plus membership and you will be saving a lot than buying it monthly or even every 6 months, if you have the time to play regularly I highly recommend this option.

review:
Five stars for looks and features, three stars for comfort and size. Install was automatic on Win 10 - plug and play. It's a little too large with buttons in awkward locations forcing you to twist tour hand to reach the buttons. The software used to configure the mouse is clunky and not very intuitive, but it does work.

The modules (wings) are clever - they attach magnetically and contacts connect with the mouse allowing the additional buttons on the modules to work.  These modules also have the additional buttons.

Overall it's a clever design, but I'd really prefer the buttons in front or further forward.

review:
Actually bought this for my wife and I, but she's hooked so I haven't had much time to play!!!  But it combines an amazing blend of 3rd person action RPG, shooter, and semi open world exploration.

A little while into the game you do unlock a fast travel option - don't fret!  But there is a lot of running around at first.  It's nice because you get to learn the basics.  But you can also run into massively overpowered foes so be careful!

The story is just amazing - very interesting, original, unique - the kind of story that leaves you pondering existence.  I guess that's why so many folks call this an existential game!

You can adjust the difficulty, so there is a super easy mode for non-gamers (like my wife) and advanced difficulty for those who enjoy punishment.  Oh and the game has 27 endings.  Folks recommend playing through at least 3.  Keep watching through credits.  No spoilers. ;)

I guess this game sold much better than Squeenix predicted, so we'll be seeing more titles from this franchise soon.  And I recommend downloading the soundtrack from Amazon for $20 - it's gorgeous.

review: This Zelda game was a hard one to review.  Automatically I liked it better than Phantom Hourglass because even though you returned to the same tower repeatedly, it didn't feel like you were backtracking.  Controlling Zelda in the metal suit was cool and added depth to the puzzles.  But everything is fine, like controls, story, graphics, all great.  But it feels like something is missing.  Maybe I just hated the traveling via train and it discouraged me from exploring around.  I didn't find a single heart piece, but I found an endless amount of treasure that I didn't use for anything, apparently it grants you train parts.  When I reached dungeons (which felt like an eternity), I absolutely loved them.  Great puzzles, great bosses, some of the graphics really blew my mind.  But it felt like I didn't care about doing anything else, which is a staple of Zelda games.  So you can see my difficulty in reviewing this game, it's definitely good, but not awesome like other Zelda games.

review: The last main Pokemon game I played was Blue and I just steamrolled through it with Venasaur.  I didn't care about type weaknesses/strengths, anything like that, and yet I was still able to beat the game.  Pokemon Gold really made steamrolling impossible (or at least more difficult).  I actually had to strategize and pick a lineup based on who I was up against.  It also introduces various pockets to organize your items which was amazing.  I really loved this game, my only complaint was after you beat the initial game, you go back to the Kanto region to earn more gym badges which sounds great on paper, but I found that all of their Pokemon were like level 30 so I destroyed all of them, until you get to the final boss Red, who's Pokemon were at insanely high levels.  So just a weird imbalance, but ultimately I loved the game.

review:
The game is fun to play and the character interactions are hilarious and feels mostly natural.  The story itself sat in the planning for way to long.  Even after having consumed the anime (free on YouTube), the movie Kingsglaive, and all other reference and source material out there, the story itself feels like a tale told so often that you skip details you think the audience already knows.  This breaks the flow of the narrative in a jarring way.  Some parts of the story move fast and amp up your drive to eat up every bit there is, but then it skips ahead, or changes the flow in a way that pulls you out of the mood to keep pressing forward.  Other times there are explanations that just lack clarity.
SE is aware of these flaws and have promised to (eventually) add free content that plugs in the holes.  New scenes, more dialogue, etc.

There are also mini-events that you need to DL, most of which are free, that give you mini-games and all to play. Most recently an Assassins Creed tie-in that rewards some neat looking outfits.  Unfortunately i don't think the new mechanics are pulled into the main game so it ends up just feeling like a show-and-tell & "look what we can do with this engine" from SE.  Some of these items are just shoehorned into the world without any (in-game) lore that links them and makes them feel like an authentic piece of the world.  What ever explanation is there is back-filled in the event itself.

The mechanics are fun but easily exploitable.  Just running around doing the side-quests you can over level to the point of breaking your character.
Still, the graphics and game play boost the heck out of the game.  Even if the rest isn't as shiny.

review:
There are games and even series I'm sure all of us at some point or another looked at that was really popular and jumped on it. Only to suddenly realize that to you it just ... sucks.

I've really tried to get into the genre. I really have. This review is written by a child from the 80s who grew up loving games like Mega Man 2 and Contra. I bring this up because to some this game is supposed to harken back to the days of NES hard. Well, I disagree. This game is just unfair.

There are games that are hard but to the point where they are challenging that want you to keep going and learn from your mistakes. This game does not do that for me. Its just as I said earlier. Its just unfair and relentless in its brutal difficulty. After giving this game and others like it hours upon hours of my time I've come to realize that every time I play this game I am not having fun. Its a grind. Its painful. Yeah I'll admit I have way more fun with games like Madden and Call of Duty. I can relax and enjoy those games. With Dark Souls III I just can't find any enjoyment here. Its pretty to look at. However, I find the controls sluggish, enemies way over powered, and an absolute chore to play.

Hey if this is your thing then cool! I'm happy for you. For me if I need to satisfy my action RPG fix I'll stick to games like Horizon: Zero Dawn and Diablo III.

review:
great stand, but this on the product page is a load of horse manure... :

"Keeps Console Cool
By positioning your PS4 vertically, the stand allows for better air circulation, which helps keep the console cool. A cooler console in turn promotes optimal performance and longer life."

For one thing, the big fan inside pushes the hot air inside out the BACK of the console, not the left side (which becomes the top when it's vertical). And hot air rises (grade school science), so any air that manages to go up instead of out the back would rise to the hard drive in the left side (now the top) and make the HD hotter while it's running.

The ONLY reason you put a console vertical (which you really don't want to do.... most PS2's that had disc drive problems were cause it was vertical, drives/cd's can wobble when not horizontal and the drives were CONSTANTLY being used for games or movies. It's better these days cause you barely use the actual disc, but still....) is if you barely have space and need the room on your entertainment center...

PS4's don't get that hot anyway...

review: This game is fairly mediocre in my opinion. It feels like a watered-down ARPG. Most reviewers seem to compare this game to Blizzard's popular game of the genre: Diablo. However, this game is only similar to Diablo in the fact that it's an ARPG, and it's displayed at a 45-degree isometric view. While this game isn't bad by any means, it's still fun to play. Character creation is lackluster, and truth be told it really doesn't need one--but I guess this game sets itself apart from others because of it. This game is more fun played with other people, and while online play is a mixed bag of skilled/non-skilled players... the single player aspect of the title felt really dull to me. Online play is where the appeal for this title is with me, otherwise it doesn't have much replayability. If I had to recommend this game, I'd probably tell a friend to pass.

review:
This game greatly improves upon its already good predecessor.
Graphics: 5/5 This game looks better than the first, and the Xbox version is the best version.
Story: 5/5 The game's story is much more complicated with new characters and locations. There are other aliens, KGB, hippies, a talking idol, and ninjas!

Destroy All Humans 2 is one of the best games from the 6th generation console era. I sure hope to get another game in the series that has so much humour and innovative sandbox gameplay.

review:
THE LAST OF US is the game that largely destroyed computer gaming for me. Prior to it I was content with the silly little plots that most games tried to use as an excuse for all of the gaming experience. But there is a distinction here: most games have stories but are not really about the story. In DIABLO, you play in order to level up and fight huge gobs of demons and zealots. In most games, you get through the story to get to the game; in THE LAST OF US, you play the game in order to get to the story. But there is more to it than that. The game play helps create the bond that Joel and Ellie feel for one another. The last chapter in Pittsburgh creates in Joel the sense that he can't allow himself to reconnect fully with another human being. There is a very small but telling moment. Joel and Ellie reach his brother Tommy. When they are alone, Tommy tells Joel he had returned to Joel's house in Austen, Texas, where the game begins; there he found a photo of Joel and Sara from 20 years previous, when the fungal outbreak began. Playing Joel you can hold the photo as long as you want, but the only action in the game is to return the photo, saying "I'm good." A couple of minutes later, Joel proposes leaving Ellie with Tommy and any other former Fireflies. Joel knows he is on the precipice. If he goes any further with Ellie, she will emotionally function as a replacement for the daughter he had lost. And sure enough, before leaving Jackson Hole, Joel has acknowledged that there was a bond between Ellie and him, one that was impossible to ignore. Joel has essentially become Ellie's father. And the flipside is equally important. In the suburbs of Pittsburgh a boy asks Ellis what she is really afraid of and after a mild attempt to evade his question she answers, "Ending up alone." So the old man who never thought he would be a father again is bonded with a girl who above all else wants someone to whom she is bonded.

Most people misread the end of the game, thinking that Joel becomes a monster. But allowing to Ellie was both emotionally and morally intolerable. It was a complete nonoption. And many assume that Ellie knew she was about to die. But her conversation with Joel belies that reading. Immediately after defeating the last group of infected - and I'm surprised so many run around in circles to elude them. You can choke out about six, use the bow on three or four others, then a thrown glass bottle to attract the others to a spot, a couple of Molotov cocktails on the mob and clean up on what is left with the flame thrower. Not even on Grounded mode have I avoided killing all of them. Any way, after dealing with all the infected in the underpass to the hospital, Ellie comments that after they are done with the Fireflies, he can teach her to swim. She was scared of possible medical procedures in Salt Lake City - this is a girl, after all, who has confessed that she was really scared of needles. As tough as she is, her fear of doctors and hospitals is set at a very low level. She was steeled to get through whatever was needed at the hospital, though clearly she did not think it would involve decapitation. She was thinking in terms of giving blood. Once Joel knew what the Fireflies intended to do, just leaving Ellie behind would have meant for him to revert to the monster he had been. It wasn't Joel who was the monster, but Marlene, who was violating her pledge to Ellie's mother to take care of her. Most who condemn Joel neglect to point out that Marlene wasn't giving Ellie any say in the matter. And one of the questions raised by the encounters Ellie and Joel have with the remnants of humanity is whether they deserve to be saved. The tragedy of the story is the lie that Joel tells to keep Ellie from learning that the woman she had thought her mother's closest friend was trying to murder her on the off chance that decapitating her would save the rest of humanity. Of course, Ellie knows at the end of the game that Joel has lied to her. She is uncertain about what the lie is and why he is telling it, but she knows that he hasn't been truthful. Dietrich Bonhoeffer, in the essay on lying - written while being interrogated in prison by the Nazis and included in the volume known by the title ETHICS - argued that being honest sometimes involved avoided stating what was factually correct, something especially true when one is trying to avoid revealing to interrogators that one is part of a conspiracy to assassinate Adolf Hitler. One could - and I in fact do - argue that being honest to Ellie meant lying to her about Marlene's intention to cut her head off so that she could remove her brain. I have been amazed that so many people have been outraged at Joel's lie to Ellie, when to me it seems clear that Joel preferred Ellie being angry at him rather than knowing that the woman who had been most concerned with her upbringing (even though she maintained some distance, putting Ellie in military school rather than raising her directly) had intended to murder her.

There are too few games like this one, games with dense content and "round" characters (in the sense described by E. M. Forster, in contrast to "flat" characters. I love games. I very much disagree with those who feel that the key to great storytelling is open ended games. Without a degree of structure, you don't really have much of a narrative. A game like Fallout 4 may force you to make some tough decisions, making you take some hard stances in the course of things, but there is no significant narrative. The Uncharted games have been reasonably interesting, though I didn't think that the characters were anywhere nearly as interesting until Uncharted 4. I have not been that impressed by the Mass Effect games as narrative, though I did enjoy them (though like a lot of others I had problems with the ending of ME3). What sets this one apart from other games is how it excels at not just at plot, but character development. Even Naughty Dog's other ongoing title, UNCHARTED, cannot even remotely compare with the kind of change we see in Joel and Ellie. At its core, TLOU is not a game about fighting zombies and humans in a post-apocalyptic America. it is about whether a 50 year old man who has been emotionally shut down for 20 can learn to love someone who is essentially his foster daughter like the daughter he lost earlier, and if a 14 year old girl will find a surrogate parent that she has always yearned for. And as I said, with all of that great character development - actually, because of that great character development - the ending possesses a degree of emotional complexity unheard of in video games.

I'll stop there, though I could go on to talk about the splendid game play and game design. A lot of people don't grasp the point of some of the game's simpler moments. A simplistic puzzle that involves carrying a ladder around some obstacles is lambasted by some as a subpar puzzle. But the point of the puzzle is to slow down the pace of the game without stopping it. In fact, the game design, just like the character development, is smart an sophisticated, even five years after its release. It may not look a cutting edge visually as it did in 2013, but lit represented a massive leap forward in showing how a game could tell a story. And now TLOU Pt. 2 is under development. Few details are available, but we know that Ellie and Joel are back, though Ellie will be more front and center. Some are speculating that Joel dies early in the game, but that seems unlikely to me. they would be anxious to give away a plot point that gargantuan in a teaser. Huge plot twists will be saved for the game itself. When will it appear? Anyone's guess. I personally thought when the announcement video appeared that it was so heavily stylized that it was impossible to tell anything about the contents of the actual game, though that didn't keep a host of people from dissecting every little detail of the teaser as if it were Holy Scripture. To me we know for certainly only a few things for certain about the game, many of them confirmed by writer, director, and producer Neil Druckman: Joel and Ellie are back; the first game was about love, but the second game is about hate; Ellie is 19 years old in the second game; a major character in the second game is played by and mocapped by Shannon Woodward of the TV comedy RAISING HOPE and robot TV SF drama WESTWORLD; Druckman's long time partner Bruce Staley is taking an extended vacation after having spent over a decade killing himself making some of the greatest games in the history of video gaming; and superstar composer Gustavo Santaolalla is returning to do what will surely be another amazing score. There may be a few more details from interviewed here and there, but the truth is that we don't know a heck of a whole lot. My personal theory is that the game will be released late next year or early in 2019. Many regard Naughty Dog to be the world's finest making of videogames and I agree. Here is hoping that they keep the major touch alive for at least one more stellar game.

review:
Never owned or freaking cared about Amiibos at all. Period. Never owned a Wii U or Switch. Only just got a new 3DS last year but still didn't see the point of Amiibo's at all. Thought they were stupid

Then Samus Returns came out. Now I think have a problem....

If your curious what you get on 3DS Samus Returns with the Amiibo's:

Zero Suit Samus = Energy Reserve Tank (energy recovery) Game Music (unlocked after beating game)
Standing Samus = Missile Reserve Tank (missile recovery) Samus Returns Concept Art Gallery (unlocked after beating game)

review: Really nicely made game. There is a decent amount of glitching, such as scenery cutting out or clipping into others or items/characters suspended in the air for no reason, and some of it can be laughable and immersion breaking. It can also be a bit frustrating so it probably isn't the best game to grab for a younger gamer or one that doesn't play games often. That said, I enjoyed it once it got the pace going and introduced the xenomorphs. The cat and mouse claustrophobia of the alien hunting you coupled with hostile androids and humans trying to scavenge makes for some fantastic and nerve wracking situations. It's a game I'd definitely play again and have plans to when I have more free time.
