review:
I was going to give NieR Automata 4 Stars, but I can't stop thinking about it.

Concept: 9/10
Aliens sent an army of robots to wipe out the Earth.  The last of the humans are on a moon base and they send battle androids back down to Earth to destroy the robot army.  You play as these androids.  The gameplay is a mix of old-school top down 2D Shooters, 3D Shooters, Shooting Platformers, and 3D Full Melee Combat with an arsenal of weaponry and of course, more shooting.  You can travel freely through an open world to find quests, fight enemies, and explore.

Story: 10/10!!!
What is life?  Where does it begin and when does it end?

Gameplay Combat: 9/10
The meat of the game is 3D combat where you can lock onto an enemy and attack, dodge, shoot, use a special weapon.  There's bullet dodging, combos, bullet shooting, special attacks, and an arsenal of weapons.  All of your weaponry is upgradeable.  The combat runs at 60fps, so it's really smooth.  You'll be able to take on 1 to 20 enemies at a time, too.  It's more fun than difficult.

The 2D shooting is pretty easy.  Enemies appear onscreen and fire at you.  You can fire back and evade.  The enemy bullets are color coded.  Orange can be shot, purple cannot.  So you have to think quickly whether you want to shoot the incoming shots or dodge.  It's fun.

3D shooting puts you in the center of the screen and the enemies appear all around you.  You use an analog stick to rotate and fire in all directions.  You can fire back and evade.  The color coded shots apply here, too.  It's not too tough and these battles are short.

2D platforming is fun.  Run to the left or right, shoot, use combo attacks, and take out enemies.  It's fast paced and not too difficult.

There are a few bosses in the game and they'll unleash a hailstorm of shots at you.  You've got to dodge and fire back.  These fights are also fun.  I only died once in combat throughout the entire game.  I thought it was easy, but I was still fully engaged when fighting enemies.

Gameplay Exploration: 6/10
The only bad thing I can say about this game is that the Map and Map Design are confusing.  The game takes place in a ruined city on Earth.  Giant skyscrapers and giant trees are all that remain.  In order to keep the game running at 60fps, the team had to reduce the draw distance.  This isn't like Assassin's Creed where you can see detailed buildings for miles around.  Instead, the map is very blocky and acts like a maze.  A quest may appear on your map and it tells you to head west, but you really need to go south, run up a giant tree branch, then head west, then north up another tree to the top of a building, then east to find a cave, then west...  It can get very frustrating just trying to find side quests.  The auto-map feature could have been implemented much better.

Gameplay Quests: 10/10
When you get optional or main quests, they are fun.  The characters are interesting and you're rewarded for your efforts.

Gameplay Upgrades: 10/10
The battle androids can be upgraded with chips that you find in the world.  You can buy them, find them, or kill to get them.  These chips can be combined to create a more powerful chip with the same ability.  For example:  If you have two Weapon +2 chips, you can combine them to create a Weapon +3 chip, which gives you an attack bonus on your weapons.  Two Weapon +3 chips will become a Weapon +4 chip.

These chips take up space on a circuit board.  The more powerful chips take up more space.  It's up to you to pick which chips you want to use.  The circuit board is also upgradeable later on in the game, allowing you to use more chips.  The chips can be swapped in and out at any time.

The types of chips available increase melee damage, ranged damage, damage when you are close to death, increase your stamina, your speed, give you, heal just before death, automatically regenerate health if you take 0 damage for x seconds, increase your melee defense, your ranged defense, your hacking skills...  It's completely up to you to Mix and Match the chips to enhance your character.

The chips are color coded when you install them.  So you can see how much space each one takes and the color tells you if it is offensive, defensive, system, or support.  It would have been easier if the names of the chips were on the chips themselves, like Ranged Defense + 2.  But they are only color coded.  This is a very minor complaint.

There is an arsenal of upgradeable weapons at your disposal.  You also have a combat pod as your companion.  This can shoot enemies and their shots, or fire a special weapon like a laser cannon or gravity bomb.  The pods are also upgradeable.  At times, you will also have another android and their pod as your companion as well.

Graphics: 8/10
The characters look great and they are stylized.  The animations are smooth; the environments, not so much.  Most of the processing power went into the characters and the fast combat.

Sound: 10/10
NieR has a great Soundtrack reminiscent of the legendary Panzer Dragoon Saga or Ghost in the Shell.  The voice acting is very well done and the combat effects punctuate the action.

Replay Value: ??? This is a unique situation
Finish the game and Continue...
You can play through the adventure again as 9S, the hacker who assists 2B the first time through.  9S is a hacker, not a fighter, so the gameplay is slightly different.  He can still run, dash, jump, and shoot, but it's easier to hack into enemies and beat them via mini-game with 9S.  When you beat the game with 9S you can continue again...
This unlocks the final act of the game.  There are 26 different endings, 5 of these are main endings for the game.
When you get a special ending, it unlocks debug tools and you can play through any part of the game or the story to experience it all.

Maturity: Teen
You can see 2B's sexy underwear and there's a lot of combat.  You just kill robots, but they act more human than the humans in most video games, so there's some emotional content as well.  Theres no blood, but there may be tears.

Overall: 9/10
The map and interface are a bit clunky at times and the environments are blah.  But, this is a great story with memorable characters that will entertain you for 20-40 hours.  It's the kind of game you think about a year after you beat it.

If you like anime style games, 3D combat with shooting, great stories, and a great OST, this is a must play.

review:
by themselves I absolutely don't recommend these for this price $150 is over priced for the sound and build quality. it's nothing really amazing, much cheaper headsets can compete with the a40 on their own. BUT pairing the a40s with mix amp for $250 although still a little over priced I do recommend that combo, I wanted these for the pc and xbox but wanted the black headset so I over paid for it. The headset arrived first and my first reaction was what did I pay $150 for here? the sound is just as good if not a little worse than my logitechs I had because the headset has very low volume for some reason without the mixamp. Once I got the mixamp in the mail there was a night and day difference, the two combined is 300% better than just the headset alone.
in summary do not just buy the headset unless you're like me and wanted the black headset but wanted them to work on the pc as well, but for some reason the black kit is for the ps4 and pc

review:
*Slight spoiler but not gonna really make a difference since its a core mechanic after like maybe less than an hour gameplay*

Ive been on a crusade  replaying all tales of * console games. Xillia 1 blew me away with the characters, gameplay, development, plot etc. It was fun and grew on me. At the end of xillia I bought this about a month ago and.. idk what to even say about it. It isn't xillia quality at all imo nor tales series quality :/  It feels like the main character is a random character model thrown into the world and doesnt say a single word while everyone else has same lovable tales quality dialogue, very little to no information on him, story is all over the place and the whole loan system ruined it for me. I haven't played more than an hour which isn't far but the beginning of the loan system ruined tie gameplay for me especially after everything that made no sense on the train..

*end spoiler*

I read alot of reviews on this AFTER unfortunatly and it turns out people barely get 18hours gameplay which is somewhat surprising given the series' history. Feels like a rushed project that relies alot on reused levels and characters to keep people engaged.

I wanted to play this to see what happens with jude, milla and the rest like a true sequel but idk if I will ever get the motivation to continue playing since its unbearable to play in comparison coming from xillia 1 :(

review:
The first 2 Bioshock were better, sorry to say, but i played it through, and it was a good game this one.

1 and 2 however, in my opinion blew this one away due to much better industrial steam punk artistic design, and much better audio.  The piano music was more nuisance than enjoyable - The audio didn't turn me on at all with this one - maybe i was just too old for this one, or maybe it was a bit more politically correct than previous versions.  I heard they upgraded the game engine on this one - ya, ok - i can see some cool playability here but they dropped the ball on the audio.  The mega fight monsters were not as creative - I just would never enjoy the more robotic effect of that... BUT SERIOUSLY, if you find a good price, this is playable, and features quite good, normal fighting with normal type controls.  I'll give it 4 stars, but I normally give 5 if I really like something.  Bioshock 1 and 2 get top rating from me.  I wish they would bring back the old, and upgrade that to the new.

review:
Instead of Dungeons and Dragons like in the first game; the South Park kids has their eyes dead set on Superheroes theme.

Like the TV show there's profanity and dark, surreal, and discriminatory humor. Instead of a wide variety of jokes (some hit-and-miss IMO) present in the South Park:The Stick of Truth; this game has a heavy focuses on fart jokes and cultural identity/race; so if you get easily offended by this then this may not be the game for you. Even the difficulty select screen has a dark racial social commentary to it.

You still play a silent protagonists, even though it directly picks off from the first game (won't spoil the ending). What's starts off as finding a missing cat, and which group of kids will dominate in making the best super hero franchise turns into something bigger that effects the whole town. Plus there's some plot twist of sorts along the way. The title is obviously a play on words if you haven't noticed, and will not click until the final act of the game

Graphics for the most part is the same from the first game, with exception of maybe more detail in the costumes and overall texture. Game does run at a solid 60fps now.

Gameplay:
You start off with 3 classes with a wide variety of super powers to choose from. This will eventually expand to more classes and abilities where you can mix-and-match

Combat is a grid based system this time around (instead of 2-sided turn based system) having some attacks, buffs and debuffs (status effects) covering a certain area of the grid. Positioning is key as some moves may have knock back features attach to them or AOE damage

There's an upgrade tree that expands once you level up. Instead of selecting individual attributes via what you wear*, you have to equip items you find or buy (in game currency) as you progress through the game.

Wearables are purely cosmetic and does not influence your stats in-game

There's also a crafting system where you combine undesirable items to better ones to use as in-game health/revives or artifacts to attach to your upgrade tree

Overall very good South Park sequel with dark social commentary, a new original story, and enhanced gameplay mechanics

review:
I have to say I really regret buying this.

This was/is my first gaming keypad and I wasn't sure I was going to like it so I opted to buy the Tartarus because it was nicer than all the really cheap ones. That said I am in love with the thing, and really wish I would have opted for the Orbweaver as it has more adjustments and functionalities.

Nevertheless onto the point, this thing is fantastic. It has really streamlined my gaming experience, and has greatly improve my immersion. With it I was able to do many things at a higher level than before and that's really what I was looking for. No more fumbling around, everything is wher you want and need it ergonomically.

The software for it is also, for the most part, straight forward and works fantastic. Being able to make presets with it and switch between games easily is a dream as well. There are a few things I wish it could do that it doesn't seem to be able to do button wise; however, that could just be me and also it is personal preference so I won't take anything away from it.

I really like it, and the membrane feels nice under my fingers. It is also very nice looking with the LED lighting.

review:
Gets old quickly.  Pretty boring game.  The missions are not thrilling at all.  This is a poor man's GTA 5 with a military theme, a nearly empty environment, and a lot of wasted time.  You don't interact much.  Not much is going on outside the main story line.  The A.I. is terrible.

The voice-acting is terrific.  The weaponry attachments and details are terrific.  The graphics are not bad at all.  But game-play is often just plain boring.  A lot of travel.  A million missions to unlock.  Stealth mechanics are faulty.

This is NOT a fast-paced game.  You need to love the details and revel in the slow, methodical approach to wasting hours of your life.

That said, not the worst buy out there.  At least it's not as slow as Monopoly.

review:
This is the most amazing headset I have ever used, but only by a small margin.  I have a very big head and ears, and the ear pads are perfect.  It is like lowering the cone of silence onto your head.  VERY comfortable.  I use the noise canceling mic and the audio adapter and it is everything you hoped it would be.  It comes with three cables, but strangely no right angle connector where it plugs into the controller - just a straight connector.  The XO7s came with better cables IMO.  The cables are rubber coated instead of cloth like the XO7.  All in all, the sound is very comparable, with a nod to the elite.  The ear cups are not comparable since the elite is lightyears better, and the part that goes across your head is pretty sweet on the elite.  The X07 creek and groan as you talk after a while due to the plastic, and so far the Elite is as quiet as a graveyard.  The cost is the only reason that I did not peg the star meter.  The X07 headset is about 90% as good at about 50% of the cost.  You would think that something this awesome would have the ability to do 7.1 audio, but alas this is not an option for whatever reason.  The augmented sound on the XBOX One X and my Windows 10 computer (not the dolby, but the windows version) is an enhancement worth using on these devices.

The video says to not use these when fully wired to a USB port because of echo issues (they recommend wireless to the XBOX).  This is not an issue for me whatsoever.  I am fully wired for the minimum lag possible, and it is perfect.  I don't know what they are talking about.

review:
To cover each of those points:

"The Dungeon Movement sucks." The camera is controlled by the L and R buttons, as well as the Dpad. Attacking an enemy while moving around has a delay that feels too long. There's three camera angles of close, far away, and awkwardly-over-the-shoulder. The enemies also appear in the over-world as a weird mass of blue blocks that clashes with just about every setting in the game.

"Combat is decent." That's a lie, this is SMT where the combat is eternally broken in your favor. Once you get demons the game becomes exponentially easier. Spoiler: that's the first five minutes of the game. Standard SMT systems for the most part, standard seven elements if you count physical, plus talking to the enemy, as is standard. Party size is lower than I'm used to for the 3DS SMT games, with only a party size of 4 active combatants at a time, as opposed to the 6 we had in Soul Hackers, or the ridiculous 12 party members at a time in the Devil Survivor games, but that actually is a good thing as it makes things feel a bit more focused, and gives a little less room to cover everything with one party, leading to strategy gaining some more importance.

"Story is standard SMT for the most part" Multiple ending paths that involve aligning with angels, demons, or just not. Setting is interesting and seems to be related to other games, but like always nothing is concrete.

"MC's hair reminds me of Mara." That wasn't a joke. Just look at it. It looks like Mara rolled around in brown paint and was slapped down on the MC's head. Poor guy, must have been traumatic.

If my opinions change on those first three points I'll come back to edit this, but that last point will likely never change.

review:
Scooby Doo First Frights is a beat 'em up game that either pays homage to, or flat out steals from, the Lego games.  The formula is pretty much the same with only minor differences.  However, if you like this kind of game play, you'll probably get your couple bucks worth.

The story is that The Mystery Inc Gang are taking a vacation, and are heading to Keystone Castle for an Eating Contest, but first they have to solve other mysteries.  These take place in a High School Musical, A creepy Carnival, a spooky coastal town, before finally going to the castle.  Classic Scooby Doo fare, so fans are sure to enjoy.

As mentioned, the gameplay borrows heavily from the Lego Games.  You fight enemies, break objects to gather scooby snacks (the currency, we'll talk about what you can buy with it later) and respawn in the same spot after death.  Like the Lego Games, it lacks challenge, but what it does not lack is charm.  There are multiple levels in each episode.  Each episode includes a chase with Shaggy and Scooby, and a boss battle, after which the crook is unmasked.  The levels give hints about who it is and try to make you think.  The third level is really the only one that does, in the others it's very obvious.  Correctly guessing the crook rewards you their mask.  After each episode, the costumes you find in the levels are available for purchase.  Before you buy them, the costumes are locked to the level they were worn in.  These costumes change their attacks and non-story based dialogue, but the abilities remain the same.

Speaking of abilities, each character has their own.  Fred is the strongman who can push and pull heavy objects or turn cranks, Daphne is agile and can climb poles, Velma is smart and can operate terminals, Shaggy has a yo-yo and can grapple, and scooby is....a dog so he can use the dog doors.  Playing the level the first time, you're locked as the characters picked for you, but you can replay the levels in explore mode, and can swap out characters on the fly (save for the very first level, and any chase or boss battle) The first level is the tutorial.  It has you play as all the characters so you can see what they can do and who you like best.  It does a good job teaching you what you need to know for the journey ahead.  The game even lets you play as the enemies...once you buy them that is.  There's also five hidden costumes that are only unlockable with cheats.  Let me save you the trouble real quick.

2839 Daphne Karate Black Belt costume
4826 Fred Knight costume
1585 Scooby-Doo Egyptian costume
3726 Shaggy Native American costume
6588 Velma Pirate outfit

The only real problems I have with the game are how long it takes to spawn a character in explore mode, and how clumsy two player mode is.  Yes, this game has co op.  But there's no split screen like the newer Lego games, so you have to stay together.  Yet when playing alone, if a character gets left behind, they teleport next to you.  That aside I really enjoy the game.

For presentation, the game NAILS that Scooby Doo vibe.  Everyone looks and sounds like they should, and they even included a laugh track. The bosses all say "And I would've gotten away with it too, if it weren't for you meddling kids!" All the classic scooby doo troupes are present and accounted for, it nearly feels like an unaired prototype Scooby Doo show in and of itself.

So that's Scooby Doo First Frights.  Is it worth your time? Well if you're looking for a challenging game, or don't like the Lego games, this won't be for you, but if you do enjoy this kind of game, or are a die hard Scooby Doo fan, you'll probably have fun with it, as it can be a nice distraction if you're bored.  Don't spend a lot for it, but do pick it up if you find it for a reasonable price.
